prompt: Facts: The case involves an appeal by the State of Rajasthan against the acquittal of the respondent, Narayan, by the High Court.; Narayan (respondent) was married to Gulab Bai (deceased).; Incident occurred during the night between 14th and 15th September 1978, in village Rampura, District Tonk, Rajasthan.; Prosecution alleged Narayan suspected his wife Gulab Bai of infidelity.; PW1 (Mst. Anchi, mother of deceased) and PW2 (Nanda, brother of deceased) testified they saw the accused and deceased together going towards their 'Bara' (enclosure) on the evening of 14th September 1978.; On the morning of 15th September 1978, Gulab Bai was found dead inside the 'Bara'.; PW3 (Kana Ram) and PW4 (Chhogalal) were among the first to discover the body.; Medical evidence (PW7 - Dr. K.C. Khandelwal) established the cause of death as asphyxia due to strangulation.; Ligature mark was found on the neck.; The accused, Narayan, was found absconding after the incident.; Prosecution alleged Narayan made an extra-judicial confession to PW10 (Gheesa Ram) on 18th September 1978, admitting he killed his wife due to her alleged illicit relations.; Based on information provided by the accused during interrogation (Section 27, Evidence Act), certain silver ornaments belonging to the deceased were recovered from his house.; A blood-stained 'dhoti' allegedly worn by the accused at the time of the offence was also recovered.; The Trial Court convicted Narayan under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment.; The High Court, on appeal by Narayan, acquitted him, disbelieving the prosecution evidence, particularly the extra-judicial confession, 'last seen' evidence, and recovery.; The State of Rajasthan appealed the acquittal to the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 302
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court erred in overturning the Trial Court's conviction by dissecting the circumstantial evidence and analysing each circumstance in isolation, rather than considering their cumulative effect.", "precedents": ["Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116", "Hanumant Govind Nargundkar v. State of M.P. (AIR 1952 SC 343)", "State of U.P. v. Ashok Kumar Srivastava (1992) 2 SCC 86"]}, {"argument": "The extra-judicial confession made to PW10 (Gheesa Ram) was reliable and corroborated by other evidence, including the recovery of ornaments and the motive.", "precedents": ["Piara Singh v. State of Punjab (1977) 4 SCC 452", "State of U.P. v. M.K. Anthony (1985) 1 SCC 505", "Gura Singh v. State of Rajasthan (2001) 2 SCC 205"]}, {"argument": "The 'last seen' evidence provided by PW1 and PW2, combined with the short time gap before the discovery of the body, strongly pointed towards the accused's involvement.", "precedents": ["State of U.P. v. Satish (2005) 3 SCC 114", "Ramreddy Rajeshkhanna Reddy v. State of A.P. (2006) 10 SCC 172", "State of Goa v. Sanjay Thakran (2007) 3 SCC 755"]}, {"argument": "The recovery of the deceased's ornaments and the blood-stained dhoti at the instance of the accused under Section 27 of the Evidence Act provides strong corroboration linking the accused to the crime.", "precedents": ["Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor (AIR 1947 PC 67)", "State of Maharashtra v. Suresh (2000) 1 SCC 471", "Mohmed Amin v. State of Maharashtra (2008) 15 SCC 38"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The High Court's acquittal was justified as the prosecution failed to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt based on the circumstantial evidence presented.", "precedents": ["Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116", "M.G. Agarwal v. State of Maharashtra (AIR 1963 SC 200)", "Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (regarding limits on appeal against acquittal)"]}, {"argument": "The evidence relied upon by the prosecution (extra-judicial confession, last seen, recovery) is weak, unreliable, and insufficient to form a complete chain pointing exclusively to the accused.", "precedents": ["Sahadevan v. State of Tamil Nadu (2012) 6 SCC 403 (on extra-judicial confessions)", "Bodhraj @ Bodha v. State of J&K (2002) 8 SCC 45 (on 'last seen' evidence)", "Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 (on burden of proof and reasonable doubt)"]}]}
